First General Session:
Frederick B. Robinson, President of the Western Massachusetts Educational
Television Council, Inc*, served as chairman. In reporting on Council activities,
the Chairman stated, in part, that: ’’Until recently, we have concentrated on
limiting the WMETV to educators. The main problem with professional educators is
they are limited in training and background and do not look at a problem as the
average person would look at it. Therefore, the Council is now going to include
businessmen, first because of their possible financial aid and second to develop
a wider awareness of the new media of mass communication for a broad understanding
of education. Most of our money has come from small institutions in this area,
who are allowed to give such funds in small amounts. Nevertheless, during these
two years that the Council has been in existence, we have made many agencies in this
part of the state aware of what can be done in TV if we could get our own station.
’’Last spring, an excellent conference was held and out of this grew another
group interested in telecasts. These are now being offered over commercial stations
by calling on teachers of the area to provide programs.
”We now depend on commercial stations for time which may be from 2:15 to 2:30
or 2:45, but it is a doubtful procedure and difficult to depend on the commercial
stations for free time. Therefore, we must increase the awareness of the potential
of ETV for adult education and in-school training. This stimulates better teach¬
ing through good teaching methods on TV. The aim is not to eliminate teachers
but to supplement them, and with this stimulation add to the value of education.
If we have accomplished nothing else, the Council is at least bringing this
awareness.”
The chairman then introduced Dr. Harry J. Skornia, NAEB Executive Director.
